dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Our black screen slowly fades to a murky blue-grey as it becomes apparent that we are underwater. From the top of screen drifts the nude body of a man, arms outstretched, sinking slowly. He moves his legs in a slight struggle as is pulled deeper and deeper into the water. His hand lash out in a final sudden movement as his body becomes still. We are now close in on the manвЂ™s face to reveal GEORGE, as he begins to toss and turn violently in the water searching for air. A title appears over our image in simple bold type: FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 30, 1962.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SNOW COVERED ROAD. DUSK
dialogues.text: George is walking in the snow. He is on a quiet stretch o road and the snow is falling gently. All is silent. Ahead George and in our line of sight is a crushed car that has flipped over on itвЂ™s top. There is broken glass everywh and the skid marks of the car are visible on the icy road The taillights are still on and there is steam coming fro the hood. A body is hanging out of a smashed window on th driver's side of the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George continues to toss and turn underwater even more violently as he struggles to find air.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SNOWY ROAD. DUSK
dialogues.text: Arriving at the wreck, George looks at the bloody face of the dead driver - it is a handsome man in his mid thirtie JIM. There is a lifeless and bloody black and white dog o the dashboard against the broken windshield.  2. George slowly lies down in the snow next to Jim. He stare at Jim's bloody face and then leans over and kisses Jim o the mouth. George pulls back. Jim's open eyes and blood covered face fill our screen as push in tighter. His eyes have a cold gelatinous feel abo them. We continue to push in until his eyes fill our scre There is a faint, repetitive banging sound, like a drum beat, in the background that becomes increasingly louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George bolts up in a panic. He canвЂ™t breathe. He is swe The drumbeat sound is loud and constant. In the distance hear a female voice.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STRUNK, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Jennifer stop it! Stop that banging now! The banging sound stops. We hear the white noise hum of waves crashing in the distance and the faint sound of seagulls. GeorgeвЂ™s face fills our screen as he recovers from the GEORGE V.O. Waking up begins with saying am and now. We gradually pull back from above to reveal a full length George. He does not look his age - a slim, tan, Englishma who has clearly taken care of himself. He has a full head of salt and pepper hair. He is handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is nude, lying on a bed, partially covered in wrinkled  3. white cotton sheets. There is a large black stain and an pen on the sheets next to him.

dialogues.speaker: AND CAN HEAR HIM BREATHING SOFTLY.
dialogues.text: A twitch of his left hand. A worn gold signet ring on the little finger. George reaches over to the other side of the bed as if searching for someone. There is an open fountain pen on t side of the bed with a small stack of stationery. The ink pen has left an enormous black stain on the sheets. Some the ink comes off on his fingers. He gains his bearings and catches his breath. He lifts hi fingers to his lips. The ink leaves a slight mark on his mouth. He lies still for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: INT: GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING 1962 -- CONTINUO GEORGE V.O. For the past eight months waking up has actually hurt. The cold realization that I am still here slowly sets in. George, with bed hair, still sweating, untangles himself from the sheets and sits up. He holds onto his head as if pain. A pile of clothes is in the chair next to the bed. Books magazines are loosely stacked next to the end table. Ther is an empty scotch bottle on the floor. The room is dark in disarray. On the floor on George's side of the bed are about 10 carefully addressed envelopes and letters laid out in a grid.  4. George looks at the alarm clock. It has stopped at 4:57. looks at his wrist watch on the bedside table. 7:22. George sighs and bangs the alarm clock a few times on the table top, winds it and resets it. The second hand is now ticking loudly.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was never terribly fond of waking up. He rises, navigates the grid of letters, and walks to the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: A SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: Relieving himself at the toilet. Standing in the shower letting the hot water wash over hi GEORGE V.O. I was never one to jump out of bed and greet the day with a smile like Jim was. Shaving.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.0., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I used to want to punch him sometimes in the morning he was so happy. Taking a handful of aspirin

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I always used to tell him that only fools greet the day with a smile, that only fools could possibly escape the simple truth that now isnвЂ™t simply now: itвЂ™s a cold reminder. One day later than yesterday, one year later than last year and that sooner or later it will come.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scrubbing his fingernails briskly with a brush.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: He used to laugh at me and then give me a kiss on the cheek INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- MINUTES LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opening an extremely organized drawer and taking out a pa of perfectly folded black socks. GEORGE V.O. It takes time in the morning for me to become George, time to adjust to what is expected of George and how he is to behave. Opening another equally organized drawer and pulling out immaculately pressed and folded white shirt.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: By the time I have dressed and put the final layer of polish on the now slightly stiff but quite perfect George I know fully what part IвЂ™m supposed to play. George runs a brush over his shoes. He dabs the back of his neck with cologne. END SERIES OF SHOTS. Standing at his dresser, George adjusts his tie and looks at himself intently in the mirror as our camera glides up George's body to his face to reveal the now fully realize public face of George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Looking in the mirror staring back at me isnвЂ™t so much a face as the expression of a predicament.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (whispering aloud to himself) Just get through the goddamn day.  GEORGE V.O. A bit melodramatic I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George walks down the hallway. As he approaches the livin room he glances out the window and sees JIM. GEORGE V.O. But then again my heart has been broken. JIM, 34, handsome and well built in a classical American is waxing a surfboard on a pair of saw horses. Two more surfboards lie on the bright green lawn behind him. A bla and white, smooth fox terrier, like the dead dog in the c lies in the sun on his side next to Jim. Another smaller, but identical dog is biting at the collar of the first do Jim is disciplining the smaller dog.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I feel as If I am sinking, drowning, canвЂ™t breathe. George stares back at Jim but his expression is suddenly changed by a sharp pain that grips his chest. He holds onto the louvered rail that separates the hall f the living room to avoid falling over. He stands still an takes a deep breath. When the pain passes, he looks back out of the window. No surfboards. No Jim. No dogs. Just a brown over-grown lawn George closes his eyes, and takes a deep breath. He makes his way down the hallway and into the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George plugs in the toaster and opens the bread box. No bread. He opens the refrigerator. No bread. He opens the freezer to find a loaf of white bread frozen solid. He dr the bread on the counter with a thud. Irritated he bangs bread several times on the kitchen counter. He abandons t loaf of bread and begins making himself a pot of coffee.  7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - DINING AREA. MORNING -- MINUTES L George is seated at the table having his morning coffee a the phone rings. George looks at his watch. 7:40. He look back at the ringing phone and decides not to answer it. FLASHBACK - INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. DAY (194 George and Jim are standing in the completely new and absolutely empty house for the first time. It is stunning The starkness of it then is a total contrast to the house today. This is the house before it had a life.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ArenвЂ™t you going to say something?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Are you kidding? ItвЂ™s spectacular George is quietly staring at Jim with a faint smile on hi face. Jim smiles when he realizes this, then slips up clo to George and moves toward him for a kiss.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing? George pushes him away. Nervously looking out of the larg plate glass window.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jim, stop it. I donвЂ™t think you're quite ready for life in a glass house.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Drapes, old man. Jim moves in for a kiss only to be held back by George.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You're the one whoвЂ™s always saying that weвЂ™re invisible.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s not exactly what I meant.  George gives in and the two men begin to kiss.

dialogues.speaker: END FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: WE PULL BACK to reveal George alone in the house, across dining area and living room and out the pivoting glass do and across the dead lawn. GeorgeвЂ™s house is modest in s yet has dynamic lines. It is an example of very bold architecture, circa 1948, that has become somewhat ramsha over time. We take in the full view of George in his worl as the phone continues to ring.

dialogues.speaker: SERIES OF SHOTS
dialogues.text: George's empty bedroom as the phone continues to ring. Surfboards leaning against a wall in the garage. Books and architectural models on the living room shelves next to a drafting table. END SERIES OF SHOTS. We cut back to George staring into space for several beat as the phone continues to ring. GEORGE V.O. For the first time in my life I canвЂ™t see my future. Every day goes by in a haze, but today I have decided will be different. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- MINUTES LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As George stands in front of his book case, the phone sta to ring again. George looks across the room at the phone which sits on a small table next to an upholstered club chair. GEORGE V.O. Finally. You know it has been raining here all day and IвЂ™ve been trapped in this house waiting for you to call.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: George is sitting in the upholstered club chair reading. is wearing glasses. He does not recognize the voice on the other end of the phone. There is a

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry. I must have the wrong number. IвЂ™m calling for Mr. George Falconer... short uncomfortable silence.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry, I was expecting someone else. Yes sir, you have indeed called the correct number. How may I help you?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: This is Harold Ackerley. IвЂ™m JimвЂ™s cousin.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh yes, of course. Good evening Mr. Ackerley.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I'm afraid IвЂ™m calling with some bad news.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: oh?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There's been a car accident.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Accident?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: There has been a lot of snow here lately and the roads have been icy. On his way into town, Jim lost control of his car.  10.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It was instantaneous apparently.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: It happened late yesterday, but his parents didnвЂ™t want to call you

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I see.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: In fact, they donвЂ™t know IвЂ™m calling you now, but I thought that you should know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know this must be quite a shock It was for all of us. George continues in his robotic state.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, indeed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Will there be a service?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The day after tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well I suppose I should get off the phone and book a plane flight.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: The service is just for family.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: For family. Of course. Well thank you for calling. (Beat) Oh, Mr. Ackerly?  ll.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: May I ask what happened to the dogs?

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Dogs? There was a dog with him but he died. Was there another one?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. A small female.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Well, I donвЂ™t know to tell you the truth. I havenвЂ™t heard anyone mention another dog

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, thank you for calling, Mr. Ackerly.

dialogues.speaker: HAROLD, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Goodbye Mr. Falconer. George replaces the receiver. As he does, it misses the cradle and falls to the floor, the dial tone continues to hum. He sits looking blankly ahead in total disbelief. He does know what to do. He slides down in the chair and begins t cry silently as the reality of what has happened sets in. suddenly jumps up, runs out of the room, down the hall, a to the front door. FLASHBACK - EXT. GEORGE'S HOUSE - CAMPHOR TREE LANE.

dialogues.speaker: EVENING, (1961)
dialogues.text: George throws the front door open and dashes out of his house, into the rain, down his driveway and up the road.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George turns onto a pathway with a steep flight of wooden stairs. The rain is torrential. George slips on the wet wooden st as he climbs to the top of the stair case and runs out on Soledad Way. FLASHBACK - EXT. CHARLEYвЂ™S DRIVEWAY. EVENING (1961)

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: George runs up the driveway towards CharleyвЂ™s house. As reaches the front door he rings the doorbell several time and begins pounding on the door. A startled blonde woman opens the door. CHARLOTTE aka CHARLEY, 47, is a British friend of George's. George throws himself at her as she embraces him and he s uncontrollably.

dialogues.speaker: END FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- 1962. The phone rings once more and then stops. George looks ba to the bookcase. He grabs a Huxley novel and retreats to the bathroom

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sitting on the toilet, George reads. There is a constant banging from outside. This is the sam banging we heard earlier. George attempts to ignore the irritating sound but finds it impossible to concentrate a slams his book shut. He looks across the street. The wind is positioned so that when on the toilet George can see o but only his head can be seen from outside.

dialogues.speaker: SAYING.
dialogues.text: The Strunk house is a pristine, absolutely new ranch hous  13. with a manicured lawn that reeks of the traditional Ameri dream circa 1962. JENNIFER STRUNK, 8, a blonde, very American little girl, hammer in hand, pulverizes an old bathroom scale that she pulled out of one of the shiny new trash cans. She tightl clutches a white Persian kitten with a pink ribbon. Jenni is wearing a gingham dress and she chants an annoying advertising jingle over and over in monotone as she pound away at the scale with the hammer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MRS. STRUNK, 32, appears in the doorway. She is the arche of the young attractive suburban wife and mother. She is usually calm and poised but today she is clearly exasperated and yells from the front door at her daughter put the scale back in the trash can. Jennifer ignores her mother and continues pounding away w increasing violence. Meanwhile, Jennifer's oldest brother TOM, 9, is combing o their lawn with a metal detector, as a younger brother CHRISTOPHER, 5, digs ferociously at the lawn with a small garden shovel. The metal detector suddenly shrieks, havin located something. Jennifer drops her cat, runs to her brothers and joins in the digging. The lawn is littered with newly excavated holes and the flower beds also seem to be in a freshly unearthed state if a dog has been digging in them. Simply put, the normal perfect front yard is an absolute disaster area. The three children start screaming loudly to their mother Mrs. Strunk rushes over to the hole to see. As the metal detector shrieks again, the children scream and even Mrs. Strunk squeals with delight and gets down on her knees to dig.

dialogues.speaker: WE CUT BACK TO GEORGE, AS HE WATCHES THE STRUNK FAMILY.
dialogues.text: MR. STRUNK, 35, a well dressed young executive with brief in hand, comes out of the house shouting at his family. His wife rushes over to him but cannot pacify him as Mr. Strunk surveys the destroyed lawn and flower beds.

dialogues.speaker: FOREGROUND CATCHING A BUTTERFLY ON A FLOWER.
dialogues.text: The Strunks continue to argue as Mr. Strunk brushes off h wifeвЂ™s attempts at affection.

dialogues.speaker: OF THE BUTTERFLY IN HIS HAND.
dialogues.text: Mrs. Strunk leans forward and kisses her husband on the cheek as he walks towards his car. Mrs. Strunk heads over to the battered scale and throws i in the trash can. As she does, she looks across the street at GeorgeвЂ™s wi to catch him staring back at her. She begins to wave. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BATHROOM. MORNING -- CONTINUOUS Embarrassed, George ducks forward to hide from view. As h does, the phone starts ringing again. He sits still for a moment. He sighs. Finally realizing t the phone will not stop ringing, he gets up. His pants ar still around his ankles as he shuffles out into the bedro to answer the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello Charley.

dialogues.speaker: BRITISH WOMAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: How did you know it was me? INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- CONTINUOUS  15. We cut to a shot of CHARLEY 48 in her bed smoking a cigarette. Her bedside table is cluttered with pill bottl and what is left of a cocktail. Her ashtray is filled wit cigarette butts and magazines are strewn around her in th bed. Strawberry blonde and fair, Charley was clearly once great beauty but is now a lonely and manic alcoholic. Charley is at the age where beauty hangs by a thread. On good day she can still manage a striking appearance yet g days are few and far between. Today is not a good day.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Charlotte, no one else ever calls me before 8:00 in the morning

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I didnвЂ™t call too early, did 1? You sound grumpy.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: No. I just have a headache. I was going to call you actually. Is it too late to change my mind about tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Of course not! I havenвЂ™t seen you all week. IвЂ™m dying for a dose of you.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I know. IвЂ™m sorry. So, great. IвЂ™11 see you tonight. I need to run though. IвЂ™m late for work. IвЂ™11 call you later from school

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I'll see you tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good-bye kiddo.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Bye, old man. We linger on Charley as she hangs up the phone. We see th joy in her face. She has a reason to live. She takes a lo  16. deep drag of her cigarette, then stubs it out and throws herself back against her bed pillows. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. MORNING -- MINUTES LATER George, now fully dressed with his jacket and eyeglasses goes to his desk and unlocks a drawer. He carefully lifts out an object and places it on his desk. We see clearly t the object is a gun. He picks it up, flicks open the revo and turns it up in the air to empty the bullets. There ar no bullets. George sighs, clicks the gun closed, and plac it in his briefcase. He then shoves a stack of papers int the briefcase along with the Huxley book and heads out th door to the hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. MORNING -- CONTINUOU George is coming down the hall. As he rushes toward the front door, he practically knocks over his cleaning woman ALVA, arriving with a bag of groceries and the newspaper under her arm. Alva is a kind, Hispanic woman in her mid 40's.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Good morning Mr. George. Alva places the bag of groceries on the dining table.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Sir, you donвЂ™t look so good. Did you not sleep again?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good morning Alva. No, I didnвЂ™t sleep well. You forgot to take the bread out of the freezer

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: It stays fresh that way.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It was a little too fresh this morning. There are some papers laid out on my desk that need to stay (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: there so please donвЂ™t move them. And my pen leaked all over the bed. IвЂ™m sorry about the sheets.

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s OK sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Alva?

dialogues.speaker: ALVA
dialogues.text: Yes sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. You're wonderful Georges crosses to the table and kisses Alva on the cheek She is stunned. George turns and leaves the house as Alva stares after him as though he is from Mars.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. GEORGE'S HOUSE. MORNING
dialogues.text: George backs his car down his driveway and into the stree The clock on the dash reads 8:04. Our camera speed slows as we see Jennifer tap dancing in driveway. Jennifer looks at George in a slightly provocat manner and tugs on her dress as he drives past. Christopher aims a toy machine gun directly at GeorgeвЂ™s and fires to squeals of laughter. George stares Christopher directly in the eye and holds u his hand in a mock gun fashion and mouths вЂњBang, bangвЂ the boy, stopping Christopher dead in his tracks. George waves at Mrs. Strunk still on her lawn watching th children play as Tom walks towards the street with an arm full of school books. She waves back - a warm smile - as George eases his car p the Strunk house.  18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George pulls into the faculty parking lot of the school. radio is on as he waits for three female students to pass front of his car.

dialogues.speaker: RADIO ANNOUNCER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Premier Nikita Krushchev said today that the Soviet UnionвЂ™s policy of peaceful coexistence averted a nuclear war over Cuba. Krushchev declared that the missiles in Cuba were ready for launching but not used, sparing the world from a nuclear holocaust... He pulls into a parking space and turns off the car. Geor closes his eyes and breathes deeply several times. He loo at himself in the rear view mirror, smooths his hair with his hand and straightens his tie. He grabs his briefcase, and gets out of his car. George makes his way through a sea of students and facult like a salmon swimming upstream. We cut to George continuing his walk as a lawn filled wit students stretches out in front of him. George notices a young couple lying together on the grass KENNY, 20, is a 3rd year student. He has dark brown hair, pale skin and piercing blue eyes. Kenny is not classicall handsome , yet is attractive in a somewhat gangly way. LO 20, is a stunning and very stylish blonde girl with a bor beatnik feel to her manner. Catching a glimpse of George, KennyвЂ™s eyes light up. We on this for a moment as KennyвЂ™s hand shoots up in an enthusiastic wave. Turning to see George, Lois offers nothing but a nod and an exhale of cigarette smoke. Georg waves back tentatively. GeorgeвЂ™s eyes linger on Kenny who is staring at him int Kenny stares after George while Lois reclines and continu  19. to smoke. Reaching the Arts Building, George heads inside.

dialogues.speaker: DAY
dialogues.text: George walks past two secretaries. One is quite a beautif blonde in her early twenties.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Good morning professor.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good morning.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Oh, professor Falconer?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: There was a student here this morning asking for your address.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My address? What was his name?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: He didnвЂ™t say sir, and IвЂ™m sorry but I didnвЂ™t ask him. He said heвЂ™s in one of your classes this term. We linger on GeorgeвЂ™s face a moment. He is intrigued by

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Did you give it to him?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: (nervous) Yes sir. I did. I hope thatвЂ™s OK. I realize I probably shouldn't have, but he was very nice and before I knew it...  20. George looks the girl up and down.

dialogues.speaker: FACE AND HAIR.
dialogues.text: George is taking in her beauty. He looks her dead in the eyes.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Your hair looks great up like that.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I said your hair looks great like that. It suits you. You always look so beautiful. Really fresh. You have such a lovely smile. George breathes in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Arpege?

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE SECRETARY
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really beautiful. George walks away. The Blonde Secretary looks back at the other girl, clearly dumbfounded at GeorgeвЂ™s manner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George enters the room and makes an effort to avoid eye contact with anyone. An older professor DON who is readin the paper looks up and smiles at George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good morning Don.

dialogues.speaker: DON
dialogues.text: Good morning George.  21. The large wall clock reads 9:10. There are two vending machines against one wall of the lounge. George grabs a cup of coffee from the coffee machine, and gets a Hershey's bar from the candy machine. George puts more change into the machine and gets a second candy bar. he does, GRANT, a tall young professor, slips next to Geo and presses the button on the coffee machine.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Good morning George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Good morning Grant. George grabs his second candy bar and heads out the door Grant follows.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: You look awful. What have you been doing? The two men exit the building and begin walking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sky is a dark brown haze. George eats his candy bar, gently steering them towards t tennis courts.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Look around Grant... most of these students aspire to nothing more than a corporate job and a desire to raise coke-drinking, TV-watching children who as soon as they can speak start chanting TV jingles and smashing things with hammers.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: You're really scaring me today George.  22.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I sometimes find them staring at me in a kind of bovine stupor as if I were lecturing in a foreign language. Remind me why we shouldnвЂ™t all just be annihilated? George scans the tennis courts out of the corner of his eye. Only one court is occupied, by two young men playing singles. The sun comes out with a sudden fierce heat that cuts thr the yellow smog-haze. The players are shirtless.

dialogues.speaker: WHACK THE BALL BACK AND FORTH.
dialogues.text: George clocks this intently and takes in every detail.

dialogues.speaker: OUTCRY FROM ONE OF THE PLAYERS.
dialogues.text: The stream of sunlight has passed and the sky is once aga dull and flat. George realizes that Grant is talking and has been talkin George has a faint smile on his face, still gazing at the players.

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: You seem to think this is all a joke. We're living in a world where nuclear war is a real threat. I donвЂ™t understand how you canвЂ™t be concerned.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're serious arenвЂ™t you?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: Yes, IвЂ™m serious. George, did you (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GRANT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: even read the article that I gave you on bomb shelters? Ours is almost done. We had 3 different contractors work on it so none of them know what weвЂ™ve got, then we're having the outside of it landscaped so no one will know itвЂ™s there.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: If word gets out that you've got a better shelter, then everyone will try to get in when something happens.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And so?

dialogues.speaker: GRANT
dialogues.text: There will be no time for sentiment when the Russians fire a missile at us.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If itвЂ™s going to be a world with no time for sentiment Grant, itвЂ™s not a world that I want to live in. One of our tennis players lets out a loud THWACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is sitting on the edge of his desk. Frozen. He has look of extreme melancholy on his face. His shoulders are slumped. He waits for the clock to strike 10:00 exactly and then h stands, picks up his briefcase and heads out the door. INT. SAN TOMAS COLLEGE - GEORGEвЂ™S CLASS -- MINUTES LATE George walks into class and places his briefcase on the desk. Most of the students continue to talk. George sits on the edge of the desk and reaches into his briefcase. He fumbles around for a moment, pauses, and th pulls out a book. He sits quietly with a slight look of disgust on his face staring directly at the talkers as, o by one, they succumb to his silence. Finally George speaks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: вЂњAfter Many a Summer Dies the Swan.вЂќ Blank stares.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I trust you've all read the Huxley novel I assigned almost three weeks ago? How does the title relate to our story? He looks around the room as a few hands go up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Mong.

dialogues.speaker: ALEX MONG
dialogues.text: It doesnвЂ™t. ItвЂ™s about this rich guy whoвЂ™s afraid heвЂ™s too old for this girl... George, irritated by the response of Mr. Mong closes his eyes tightly and takes a deep breath as our sound fades.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: George is tossing and turning underwater struggling to breathe. He turns over and over trying to find the surfac the water but he continues to sink.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. SAN TOMAS COLLEGE - GEORGEвЂ™S CLASS -- MOMENTS LATE Our sound returns as George opens his eyes and snaps back the present. Laughter dies away. The only one not laughin is Kenny, who is watching George intently. George remains frozen for a moment as RUSS raises his hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Russ? George signals for Russ to speak. Our camera speed slows and our sound fades as George seem mesmerized by the blank eyes of Lois. Lois is smoking and staring straight back at George in an almost aggressive manner. She begins to whisper into KennyвЂ™s ear. Kenny continues to watch George who has a dazed expression on h face. George slowly regains his composure and comes to attentio as MYRON - a dark-complexioned young man with intense eye and glasses- raises his hand. OUR SOUND RETURNS.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Hirsch.

dialogues.speaker: MYRON
dialogues.text: Sir, on page 79, Mr. Propter says that the stupidest text in the Bible is: вЂњthey hated me without a cause." Does he mean the Nazis were right to hate the Jews? Is Huxley an anti-Semite?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No.  26. The class stares at George, expecting more from such a provocative question.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: No, Mr. Huxley is not an anti Semite. The Nazis were obviously wrong to hate the Jews. But their hating the Jews was not without a cause... But the cause wasnвЂ™t real. The cause was imagined. The cause was FEAR. Curious stares.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s leave the Jews out of this for a moment and think of another minority. One that can go unnoticed if it needs to. George looks directly at WALTER, a slightly effeminate yo man, who turns away embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: There are all sorts of minorities, blondes for example, but a minority is only thought of as one when it constitutes some kind of threat to the majority. A real threat or an imagined one. And therein lies the FEAR. And, if the minority is somehow invisible... Another glance at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: .+:the fear is even greater Kenny tries to find the target of GeorgeвЂ™s glance, but avail.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And this FEAR is the reason the minority is persecuted. So, there (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: always is a cause. And the cause is FEAR. Minorities are just people. People... Again a subtle look at Walter.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: +.+like us. Walter shrinks in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I can see that IвЂ™ve lost you a bit. You know what? LetвЂ™s forget about Huxley today. George places his book on his desk. Several students look from their notebooks.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s just talk about fear. Fear after all, is our real enemy. Fear is taking over our world. Fear is being used as a tool of manipulation in our society. ItвЂ™s how politicians peddle policy and how Madison Avenue sells us things that we donвЂ™t need. Think about it. Fear that weвЂ™re going to be attacked, fear that there are communists lurking around every corner, fear that some little Caribbean country that doesnвЂ™t believe in our way of life poses a threat to us. Fear that black culture may take over the world. Fear of Elvis PresleyвЂ™s hips. (beat) Well, maybe that one is a real fear. Fear that our bad breath might ruin our friendships... Fear of growing old and being alone. George notices a few eyes looking over his shoulder at th clock on the wall which reads 12:05.  28.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Fear that we're useless and that no one cares what we have to say. Some shift about uncomfortably in their seats, yet Kenny stares, amazed. George surveys the anxious class, realizing he has lost their attention.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Have a good weekend. George closes his book, shoves it in his briefcase, and walks out the door as his students gather their things. Kenny gets up to follow after George but Lois corners him talk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is heading briskly towards the administration building when he hears Kenny's voice.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Sir! May I speak to you for a minute? I have to go down to the bookstore. George pauses allowing Kenny to catch up to him and then two men begin walking. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Why donвЂ™t you talk to us like that all the time?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t think it went over very well.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Man, fear of things gets to me all the time, but you canвЂ™t talk about it with anyone or you just sound like a fool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You canвЂ™t even talk about it with Lois?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t think sheвЂ™s afraid of anything.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Everyone's afraid of something Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: What are you afraid of sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Cars.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: How can you live in Los Angeles and be afraid of cars?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Maybe you canвЂ™t.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Sometimes my fear of things can almost paralyze me. ItвЂ™s like I get really panic stricken and I feel like I might explode or something... May I ask you a personal question sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Do you ever get high? George stops walking.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: How old do I look to you?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Have you ever taken any drugs sir?  30.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course, Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I shouldn't really be discussing this with you on campus Mr. Potter. George begins walking and Kenny follows.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s the only way I get by sometimes. Have you ever tried mescaline?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Not my drug of choice. I shaved off one of my eyebrows once on mescaline. Not a good look for me

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I looked in the mirror - big mistake if you're high on mescaline - and decided that my eyebrows were taking over my face and before I knew it, I had shaved one off. I wore a band-aid over my eye for about 6 weeks while my brow grew in. Very embarrassing.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: You didnвЂ™t take it again after that? George stops.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Kenny, have you been listening to me? I shaved off my eyebrow. I wanted an experience Mr. Potter, not a career on stage.  31.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: If you ever want to get high sir, I usually have some dope.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're really mad arenвЂ™t you?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir. I guess you donвЂ™t feel very comfortable talking like this.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What makes you say that?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Lois thinks youвЂ™re kind of cagey. Like this morning, when you were listening to all that crap we were talking about Huxley...

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, not all of you. I didnвЂ™t notice you open your mouth once.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I was watching you. George is surprised and intrigued. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) You let us ramble on and on and then you straighten us out - but you never really tell us everything you know about something

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, maybe thatвЂ™s true up to a point.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s not that I want to be cagey. I canвЂ™t really discuss things completely openly at school Someone would misunderstand... I tried to do that today. It doesnвЂ™t work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny seems to be thinking over what George has said as t two men enter the bookstore. Kenny picks up a red pencil sharpener from a display on the counter and a note book.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: What was it you wanted to get sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Nothing. I was on my way to the DeanвЂ™s office.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: You mean you walked all the way down here just to talk to me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Well, I think you deserve something for that. Here sir, take your pick ItвЂ™s on me. Kenny waves his hand across the multicolored display of pencil sharpeners.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. George chooses a yellow one.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I thought you'd probably pick blue. Kenny pays the cashier.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why blue?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Isn't blue supposed to be spiritual?  33.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What makes you think IвЂ™m spiritual? And you? Red?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s red stand for?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Lots of things. Rage. Lust.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: No kidding? Kenny looks George straight in the eye. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) See you around, sir. Kenny smiles and walks away leaving George staring after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is cleaning up his office. He is arranging the ins of his drawers and throwing things into the garbage can. is all immaculate. His desk is absolutely bare with the exception of three file folders carefully labeled and lai out precisely on his desk top. George sits down and sighs. He rests his head in his hand for a few moments and rubs his temples. He opens his briefcase, searching for something. He locat a bottle of aspirin, and empties 3 tablets into his hand. He opens his lower desk drawer and pulls out a near empty bottle of scotch. He unscrews the cap and finishes the bo off, as he washes down the aspirin. He picks up the phone and dials a number.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Hello?  34.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you up to kiddo? INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - DRESSING ROOM. DAY -- CONTINUOUS Charley's hair is teased up but has not yet had itвЂ™s fi brush out and last coat of lacquer. Her foundation is on the rest of her makeup is not yet done and her face is ma beige. She has a picture ripped out of Vogue on her dress top about how to achieve the вЂњPerfect Doe EyeвЂќ. One e made up and the other is bare. We are staring at her in a magnifying mirror. There are dresses strewn around the ro A Serge Gainsbourg record is playing in the background.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Just trying to finish up a book How's your day going?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.8)
dialogues.text: Fine. I was just getting ready to leave school and wanted to know if you needed anything for tonight?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You're sweet, but thanks, I think IвЂ™m all set. She is looking at herself in the magnifying mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, could you pick up a bottle of Gin for me? Tangueray? I love the color of the bottle.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You love whatвЂ™s in it. What time do you want me?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: 7:00 would be great if thatвЂ™s OK with you.  35.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Perfect. I'll see you tonight. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. DAY -- CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I'll see you then. Bye Geo.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Good-bye kiddo. She hangs up the phone and starts back to work on her fac She does a little dance move to the record and stares int the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Beautiful...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We cut back to GEORGEвЂ™S P.0.V. He looks at the clock on wall. 2:20. George takes one of the folders off of his de and slips it into his briefcase as he walks to the door. He turns, and looks around the room for a moment. He turns off the light and closes the door as he leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exiting the faculty building, George crosses the campus t the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: LOT DAY
dialogues.text: George is inside his car with his briefcase open. He is looking for his car keys. He spots the handle of the gun wraps his fingers around it. He is deep in thought. There is a loud startling knock on GeorgeвЂ™s window. Itв Kenny. He is on his motorcycle and has pulled up next to George. He turns off his motor. George rolls down the car window. George is in a dark mood as he quickly closes the  36. briefcase, irritated that he has been disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Potter?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That is usually why people get into their cars.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: No, I mean are you going on vacation or something?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I saw you cleaning out your office. George's face goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What is it that you really want Kenny?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I was just hoping that perhaps we could get together for a drink or something sometime.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And why is that?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know sir. Because I think you might like it. I mean, because you seem as though you could use a friend.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh really?  37.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: (sincerely) Yes sir, you do. George looks Kenny in the eyes. He is touched by KennyвЂ™ concern.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, you might be right Kenny, but we'll have to make it another time IвЂ™m late. (beat) But thank you for the invitation. And thank you for the talk earlier. And stay away from the mescaline. George starts his car and pulls out of the driveway and onto a winding side street leaving Kenny sitting on his motorcycle in the parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SANTA MONICA NATIONAL BANK. DAY
dialogues.text: George passes a security guard who nods at him. As George walks up to a desk marked вЂњSafe DepositвЂќ, a brunette, BANK TELLER, greets him. She clearly finds him attractive.

dialogues.speaker: BANK TELLER
dialogues.text: Hello Mr. Falconer.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Hello. How are you today?

dialogues.speaker: BANK TELLER
dialogues.text: Fine, sir. Do you need to get into your box?

dialogues.speaker: BANK TELLER
dialogues.text: Here you are sir. Can you sign here please? George signs.  38.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you. As the teller leaves, George opens the box and slowly empties the contents. He pulls out folded documents and pushes them into his briefcase. He takes out a slim gold wedding band, looks at it for a moment and then slips it onto his little finger next to h signet ring. A black and white photograph in the box catches GeorgeвЂ™ eye. INSERT PHOTO: it is a nude picture of Jim lying on a larg boulder in the sun. As George stares at the photo, he closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: HARSH SUN. THERE IS A SOUND OF RUSTLING PALM LEAVES AND
dialogues.text: WIND. WE SLIDE ALONG A MANвЂ™S BODY AND ARE SUDDENLY PULL

dialogues.speaker: DESERT CAPTURE THE REMOTE AND BEAUTIFUL EMPTINESS OF IT A
dialogues.text: George, 38, and Jim, 21, lay on a large smooth boulder on high cliff edge, propped up on their elbows, admiring the peaceful and seemingly empty desert. There is a camera in the foreground. Jim is buttoning up his pants.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: So explain your friend Charlotte to me

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What would you like to know?  39.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You seem very... I donвЂ™t know... intimate I guess. Like you were once together. You haven't ever slept with her have you?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. A few times when we were young. I donвЂ™t mean to say that it didnвЂ™t mean anything to me but, IвЂ™m afraid it meant a good deal more to Charley. It was a long time ago in London. It didnвЂ™t work out very well. I love Charley and we are very close friends but thatвЂ™s all.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m confused. If you sleep with women then why are you with me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Because I fall in love with men Because I fell in love with you Anyway, doesnвЂ™t everyone sleep with women when theyвЂ™re young?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I haven't.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're joking.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: No. IвЂ™m not. It was just never anything that interested me

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well. You're awfully modern aren't you? You know, that was the first thing that I noticed about you was how sure of yourself you were. How can you be so sure about everything at your age?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You think IвЂ™m sure of myself?  40.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course you are. George lets his hand brush against JimвЂ™s. Jim looks at George then breaks into a great smile.

dialogues.speaker: ROOM. DAY
dialogues.text: George slips the photo into his jacket pocket. He closes empty box and picks up the beige phone on the desk.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m finished now. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: BANK TELLER
dialogues.text: Yes, Mr. Falconer... Is there something else we can help you with today? George is looking through his briefcase.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I canвЂ™t find my check book and I need some cash. Not my day IвЂ™m afraid. Excuse me a minute. George sits down on a trim upholstered sofa and starts to look carefully through his briefcase. Into our frame come two perfect, tiny blue patent leather shoes. George looks up to see Jennifer Strunk. Her beauty is almost alarming. Her blue eyes match the color of her tin shoes. She stares at George intently.

dialogues.speaker: OF THE BREEZE CREATED BY THEM IS AMPLIFIED.
dialogues.text: George is dumbstruck. The little girl looks up at him wit absolute innocence. She is holding a small glass terrariu

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Mommy says bushy eyebrows are pedestrian, but I think yours are pretty.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well I think yours are pretty too.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Why do you look so sad? Would you like to meet Charlton Heston?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What? Jennifer holds out her terrarium. It has paper columns gl around the outside and inside is a large black scorpion a a small spider clinging to a stick.

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: Ben Hur. Our scorpion. Every night we throw in something new to him and watch him kill it. Daddy says itвЂ™s like the colosseum so my brother Tom glued on all the columns. He wants to be a set designer. He hasnвЂ™t eaten the spider yet cause heвЂ™s still full from the moth we gave him last night. Daddy said heвЂ™d like to throw you in the colosseum.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No kidding. why?

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER
dialogues.text: He says you're light in your loafers but you arenвЂ™t even wearing loafers. I think my brother Tom is (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JENNIFER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: light in his loafers too but he wears Keds. Last week he made me do a conditioning treatment on my hair with eggs. Does it look shiny? Mrs. Strunk appears suddenly. She looks lovely with her light brown hair swept up in a french twist.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STRUNK
dialogues.text: Sweetheart, what are you doing bothering Mr. Falconer?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s not bothering me at all Susan. How are you?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STRUNK
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m glad to see you George... George, weвЂ™re having a few people over tonight for drinks and would love to have you join us if you could.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thank you, itвЂ™s very kind of you but IвЂ™m afraid that I have plans tonight.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. STRUNK
dialogues.text: Well, another time then. Come on Jennifer. LetвЂ™s let Mr. Falconer get back to his banking. Goodbye George.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Goodbye Susan. Goodbye Jennifer The two women walk away and George looks after them with faint smile. Jennifer turns and stares back at George and flashes her blue eyes at him. He is left smiling back at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are rows of guns on the wall behind the counter and innocuous music plays in the background. A YOUNG BOY, 14, behind the counter helping a PRETTY BLONDE GIRL with a ri George walks up to the counter and places his gun down.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY
dialogues.text: May I help you sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I need a box of bullets for this gun.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. The boy picks up the gun and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BOY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: This is a really old gun sir. we have a two for one sale on handguns at the moment. Perhaps one for the little lady?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No thanks. Just the bullets please. George hands the boy money for the bullets.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. LIQUOR STORE. PARKING LOT. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: A giant billboard for PSYCHO featuring only Janet LeighвЂ eyes completely fills our frame as GeorgeвЂ™s car pulls i our shot. George parks and gets out of the car and walks towards the liquor store. The sun is low in the sky, and the sky is now a dirty sha of pale orange. As George passes a late model car, a dog is barking hysterically and looking out of the driverвЂ™s side windo George. It is a smooth, black and white fox terrier. Geor stops in his tracks, approaches the car and stares in the window as the dog becomes silent and looks George in the eyes.  44a. Just then a YOUNG WOMAN returns to the car.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry. I hope she didnвЂ™t growl at you. She goes kind of crazy sometimes when I have to leave her in the car. The Young Woman opens her car door and pushes the dog asi with her bag.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s perfect. WhatвЂ™s her name? The Young Woman gets inside and rolls down the window. Th dog climbs onto her lap and puts her front paws on the ca door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: India.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I used to have smooth fox terriers. You donвЂ™t see them very often

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DEEP BREATH OF INDIAвЂ™S NECK AND EAR. HE NUZZLES HER AND

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: SheвЂ™s still a puppy isnвЂ™t she? George pulls back. The Young Woman is slightly taken abac by George but flattered. She nods and then smiles.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG WOMAN
dialogues.text: Have a nice evening.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You too. Good night India George watches as the car pulls away. India now on the passenger seat looks back at George. George heads toward the front of the store.  45. As George walks toward the door we see CARLOS, 20, a hust in a leather jacket, tight jeans, boots and a t-shirt loitering near a pay phone smoking a cigarette. He is ver handsome in a cheap way and locks eyes with George as Geo enters the electric doors. George looks away uncomfortably. EXT. LIQUOR STORE. LATE AFTERNOON -- MOMENTS LATER. As George exits the liquor store with two bottles in brow paper bags, Carlos turns to enter and the two men walk ri into each other as GeorgeвЂ™s gin crashes to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Man, IвЂ™m sorry about that.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s OK. CarlosвЂ™ pack of cigarettes is on the ground covered in and glass.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It was my fault. 1/11 get you another pack. Carlos smiles and looks right into GeorgeвЂ™s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, no I insist.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIQUOR STORE. LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: The CASHIER slips George's bottle of gin into a brown pap bag and hands him a pack of Lucky Strikes and a book of matches. George hands the cashier a 10 dollar bill and sh gives him change.

dialogues.speaker: CASHIER
dialogues.text: Thank you sir.  46. The cashier glares at Carlos as he walks towards the door

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry about the broken glass. Thank you. George hands the cigarettes to Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Here you go.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Thanks man. Carlos opens the pack as the two of them walk through the glass doors.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: You want one?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No thanks. George stares into CarlosвЂ™ face. His beauty is stunning

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, yes actually. Why not. Thank you. George takes a cigarette and Carlos lights it as George gazes into his eyes. CLOSE UP SHOTS OF CARLOSвЂ™ EYES AND LASHES. DETAILS OF H

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Carlos.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What did you say?  47.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Carlos. You asked me my name. Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, yeah, yeah. IвЂ™m sorry. George takes a last deep inhale as he looks Carlos up and down and then settles on his face.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (in perfect Spanish) Wow. You're really something. You have an incredible face. Enjoy that. ItвЂ™s a great gift.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Your Spanish is perfect.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Thanks. I should have used it more.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) ItвЂ™s not too late. George stubs out his cigarette and then reaches into his jacket pocket and pulls out a 20 dollar bill. He hands it Carlos. George walks toward his car and starts to get in, but as does he notices Carlos trying to open the locked passenge door. Our shot is from the front of the car, taking in the sky the background which has turned a vivid pink.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: ArenвЂ™t we going somewhere?  48.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. But, thanks. Looking up at the sky, George stops and stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You know itвЂ™s the smog that makes it that color.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I've never seen a sky like this before.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) Sometimes awful things have their own kind of beauty. George looks at Carlos, struck by his comment.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Could I have another cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Sure. George walks around to the back of the car. Carlos gives George a cigarette and places one in his own mouth, strik a match and lights GeorgeвЂ™s cigarette and then his own. George and Carlos sit on the trunk of the car and stare a the sky.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You sure that you donвЂ™t want to go for a drive?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sure. (Beat) Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Madrid.  49.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Madrid? How did you get here?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s a long story. I met a guy from LA at the hotel where I worked who told me I could live with him and that he could get me an agent. I never realized that I had a Spanish accent.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I like your accent. You speak very well. How did you learn English?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: My mom had an American boyfriend when I was little.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is your mother in Madrid?

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Yeah. She cuts hair. She cut my hair before I left. Do you like it? I thought it made me look like James Dean.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You look better than James Dean

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Really? Thanks. (beat) No one has ever picked me up and not wanted something.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think you picked me up. (Beat) Today is kind of a serious day for me

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: Come on. What could be so serious for a guy like you?  50.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, IвЂ™m just trying to get over an old love I guess.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: My mother always says that lovers are like buses. You just have to wait a little while and another one comes along. George stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You have a smart mother. IвЂ™ve got to go.

dialogues.speaker: CARLOS
dialogues.text: (in Spanish) You seem like all you really need is someone to like you. IвЂ™m a nice guy you know. George goes around to the drivers side of the car and sta to get in.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Thanks, but IвЂ™m going away. George backs up the car and waves quickly to Carlos as he pulls out of the parking lot. Carlos stares after the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George, in a crisp white shirt with french cuffs, is wash his hands and dressing for dinner as a very loud cocktail party sound blasts from the Strunk house. George looks out his window to survey all of this. The Strunk lawn is pristine, flower beds immaculate, and guests are arriving. All are dressed in their best, chic cocktail outfits and the driveway is full of sleek, late- model cars.  51. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. EVENING -- MOMENTS LATER

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is increasingly irritated at the sound of the part He walks over to his Hi Fi and starts to put on a record. As he does he glances back at the sofa.....

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: Jim and George are stretched out on the small sofa readin with their heads at opposite ends. A fire is burning in t fireplace. There is a beer on the floor at JimвЂ™s end and a scotch floor at GeorgeвЂ™s end. The female dog is tucked up between them and the male is stretched out on the floor as a record ends and starts to scratch back and forth.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s your turn to change it.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m not changing it. ItвЂ™s your turn. You wonвЂ™t like what I put on anyway.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, please, please. Come on. IвЂ™11 give you five dollars if you change it. Please. I donвЂ™t want to. IвЂ™m too old to get up.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You're only old when itвЂ™s convenient for you to be old. What are you reading? George flashes the cover of Kafka's Metamorphosis at him.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no. Not that depressing crap again.  52.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s for my class. And what highbrow work of fiction might you be reading? Jim flashes the cover of Breakfast at TiffanyвЂ™s.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hmmm.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Don't be so smug. The dog on the floor sits up.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to the dog) And just what do you want?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: He wants to go out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Of course he does. What a life he has. DonвЂ™t you envy him?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why, because he gets to sniff anyoneвЂ™s ass he wants to?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Nice. I envy him because he just does what he wants. Like yesterday I was standing in the front yard, and Susan came over to talk for a minute and that little brat of hers, Christopher came running over with that damned gun of his. Well our little dog walked right up, looked straight ahead, hiked his leg and peed all over Christopher's new tennis shoes. And all over Christopher actually. He and his (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: mother both started shrieking and I had to act like I was upset, when it was all I could do to keep from laughing. It was so perfectly executed after all the times those kids have tortured that poor dog. I wish you had seen it. They both laugh and look at the dog who knows that he is being spoken about.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You should take a lesson from him. He doesnвЂ™t stay up all night worrying. HeвЂ™s figured out how to get the two of us to do exactly what he wants. They are both basically very sophisticated little parasites when you think about it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, the dumbest creatures are the happiest. Just look at your mother

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: You're an ass. What I mean is, he really just lives in the moment. Like now. What could be better than this? Tucked up here with you. If I died right now it would be OK.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, it wouldnвЂ™t be OK with me so shut up and go change the record.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Good answer. Jim starts to get up.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was going to take them with me to Denver next week if itвЂ™s OK with (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: you. My mom loves them. ItвЂ™s probably that recognition of a similar mind. Jim kisses George on the forehead.

dialogues.speaker: JIM, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh, you stay there old man. You owe me five bucks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George looks towards the Strunk house again. He is irrita at the noise from the party and puts on the record.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Opera music is now blaring. George, is re-arranging the items on his desk. He takes a dark suit out of the closet and lays it across the empty end of the desk top. He goes over to his dresse pulls out a shirt, takes a pair of gold cuff links out of ebony box on the dresser top and lays these out next to t suit. He goes back to his closet and grabs two different ties. He stands over the suit weighing the two different tie options. He chooses one, lays it on the shirt carefully a returns the other one to the closet. He carefully writes out something in bold type on a small piece of paper and pins it to the tie that he has laid ou with the shirt. He takes a note marked вЂњCharleyвЂќ from desk top and lays this on top of the suit. George goes to his closet, takes out a pair of black capp toe shoes and places them on the desk next to the suit. T shoes are perfectly polished. He stands back and surveys desk.  55.

dialogues.speaker: AND 3 CAREFULLY LABELED KEYS. THE LARGE BOX AT THE END OF
dialogues.text: THE DESK IS MARKED вЂњCHARLEYвЂќ. THE OTHER END OF THE DE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND A NOTE THAT SAYS вЂњWINDSOR KNOTвЂќ AT THE NECK. George takes the gun from his desk and goes over to his s of the bed. He lays down. He opens his mouth and carefull inserts the tip of the gun. He lies like this for a momen sits up, looks at the wall behind him and the pillows on bed and gets up and heads toward the bathroom with the gu in his hand. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BATHROOM. EVENING -- CONTINUOUS George gets into the shower and pulls the shower curtain closed. Our shot is from the OUTSIDE OF THE SHOWER and we can see George's silhouette as he raises the gun to his mouth. He turns and looks behind himself. He repeats the motion of placing the gun in his mouth but this time fall back against the wall and slides down it. George yanks th curtain open and goes out of the door and down the hall. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - BEDROOM. EVENING -- MOMENTS LATER George comes back into the bedroom with a red flannel sleeping bag. The gun is still in his hand. He unrolls th sleeping bag and places it on the bed. He gets in and zip it up over his head. We can see by the shape of the sleep bag that he has raised the gun to his mouth. Just as he d this, the phone rings. George freezes for a moment, then gets out of the sleeping bag and crosses the room. He pla the gun on his desk and answers the phone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I did not forget the gin. IвЂ™11 see you in ten minutes He hangs up the phone and heads down the hall.  56. EXT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - KITCHEN. EVENING -- MINUTES LATER George is standing at the kitchen counter putting the finishing touches on a note. He is now dressed in a blazer with gold buttons, grey sla and black loafers. He has clearly made an effort to look handsome. He folds the note around a stack of one hundred dollar bi and puts it into an envelope. He writes ALVA on the outsi of the envelope, goes to the bread box and pulls out a ne loaf of bread. He opens the wrapper and slides the envelope in so that i is visible through the plastic. He closes the wrapper and places the loaf of bread in the freezer. He grabs the liquor bottles and heads out the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George leaves his house and begins to walk down his drive The Strunk cocktail party is now in full swing and two couples are being greeted at the front door by Mr. Strunk All of a sudden, Christopher Strunk jumps out of the bush with his toy machine gun and starts shooting at George. George stares down at the little boy.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Our sound fades as George slowly turns towards the boy, unzips his fly, and unleashes a steady stream of piss all over the stunned kid who starts screaming hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: Our sound snaps back. George is still staring at Christop who is shooting away. GeorgeвЂ™s stare brings the little to a stop.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Christopher, would you like it if I killed you?

dialogues.speaker: CHRISTOPHER
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know.  57.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, if you keep it up we are going to find out, so go home and stop shooting at people. Christopher glares at George. George offers a quick salutation and a broad smile to Mr. Strunk and then turns and walks up the road.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STAIRS TO SOLEDAD WAY. NIGHT
dialogues.text: George walks up the stairs with his bottles of liquor. EXT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - DRIVEWAY. NIGHT George walks towards the house. He stares at the door a moment before ringing the bell. George is stunned by the beauty of the lush pink climbing roses next to CharleyвЂ™s door. He leans in to smell one closes his eyes. Charley opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Geo.

dialogues.speaker: OUR CAMERA DRINKS CHARLIE IN
dialogues.text: Charley is dressed in a graphic black and white evening dress that is clearly a few years ahead of itвЂ™s time. H strawberry blonde shoulder-length hair is teased and pile on her head in a stylish coif that clearly took a great d of time to achieve. This is Charley at her best and not t same Charley we saw earlier. She has made quite an effort and she looks beautiful. She kisses George on the cheek as they embrace.

dialogues.speaker: ARMS.
dialogues.text: Back to the present, George pulls away from Charley.  58.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You look divine. As chic as ever. George is genuinely happy to see Charley.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Come on in. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - ENTRY HALL. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS George follows Charley as they walk together through the house.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Oh God. It smells awfully of cooking in here doesnвЂ™t it?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It smells great. IвЂ™m starving WhereвЂ™s Louisa? INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - SUN ROOM. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I gave her the night off. IвЂ™m cooking myself.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You are?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, and IвЂ™m trying something new.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Charley darling, you cooking is new.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t be smart. IвЂ™m in a good mood tonight and IвЂ™m going to be fun IвЂ™ve made two early New Years resolutions. One, no more talk about awful ex-husbands and children who donвЂ™t give a damn  59.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And the other one?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: One what?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Resolution.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Oh, resolution number two! More smoking and more drinking and screw it all! So, come mix me up a drink I'll have a gin and tonic please and watch out baby!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Coming up. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS The interior of the living room is almost all white. This is very definitely the house of a stylish woman. There is white shag carpet on the floor, a fire burning, a large curved sectional sofa in the center of the room and an elaborate dining table set for two in a window at the far end of the room. As they walk into the living room George turns to the wel stocked drinks table and mixes them both a drink. Charley sits down on the sofa in front of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: It was sweet of you to come tonight.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sweet had nothing to do with it. I needed to see you.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Oh come off it. Whenever you do something sweet, you're too ashamed to admit it.  60. George hands Charley her drink and sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: To our early New Years Resolutions.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: And just what are your resolutions by the way?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: To let go of the past. Completely, entirely, and forever. They raise their glasses and smile at each other. Charley looks George up and down.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Light me up Geo, will you... Charley looks Geo in the eyes. George leans forward for t table lighter.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Darling, you donвЂ™t look well. Do you remember when you had your little heart attack last year?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: It wasnвЂ™t a heart attack.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Well whatever it was darling you donвЂ™t look so hot.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m great. Never been better. Just tired. I haven't been sleeping

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Geo, itвЂ™s normal. You were with Jim for 16 years. I think about Richard everyday too. ItвЂ™s hard being alone. At least you have a job and a life. (beat) LetвЂ™s have a bit of dinner shall we? Because IвЂ™ve worked so hard...  61. INT. CHARLEYвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- LATER They've finished their dinner, and a bottle of champagne.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Really? Charley lights another cigarette. CHARLEY (CONTвЂ™D) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Seriously, вЂњoldвЂќ doesnвЂ™t exist anymore. A student yesterday called me a вЂњsenior citizenвЂќ.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I wouldn't mind if вЂњoldвЂќ didnвЂ™t exist, but IвЂ™m not sure вЂњseniorвЂќ is what IвЂ™m shooting for either Charley catches a reflection of herself in the glass of the window and smooths her cheek up a bit with her well manicured hand.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s all becoming so bland... itвЂ™s not why I came to America. ItвЂ™s like a complete breakdown of culture and manners.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Well, the young ones have no manners. The other day at the car wash I had a young man look me up and down and actually ask me if I was a natural blonde!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No. What did you say?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I looked him straight in the eye (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: and said: вЂњWell, letвЂ™s just say that if I stood on my head I would be a natural brunette with lovely breath.вЂќ

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You did not!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I did! And the amusing thing was that it went right over his head! They both laugh hysterically.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You had a mouth on you even back in London. Do you remember that old lesbian who threw her drink at you because you asked her if she was hung like a donut!? They practically fall out of their chairs laughing at thi one. Their laughing tapers off as Charley takes a drag on her cigarette. There is a quiet, sweet pause between them

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Oh Geo, we could always go back to London. The two of us.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No thanks.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You know you miss it.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Sometimes I miss it. Maybe if Jim had lived. He loved England. He really wanted us to stay the last time we were there.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Do you really think you would have moved?  63.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I donвЂ™t know. ItвЂ™s silly to even talk about it. It was just a fantasy. Charley reaches over and holds his hand. As she does, she fondles his little finger and notices the addition of the slim gold band.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s this? George pulls his hand away.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: My motherвЂ™s wedding ring. I found it when I was cleaning out a drawer. Charlotte dear, we are both in need of another drink George stands up, grabs their two empty glasses, and head back to the drinks table as Charley watches, clearly stil very much in love. Charley gets up and puts on a record and then crosses the room to where George is mixing the drinks and slides up behind him affectionately. George smiles as Charley embraces him from behind and lay her head on his shoulder. Much to her surprise he turns around, takes her hand, and grabs her around the waist as they begin to slow dance. George buries his head in CharleyвЂ™s neck and squeezes h close. We hear the sound of her bracelets and George feel the brush of her earrings as he literally drinks her in. They are drunk and adorable together as the pace of the music slows and George starts to pull away. Charley in an attempt to keep things going stops dancing and runs across the room to change the record.  64.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Wait, wait, wait! DonвЂ™t move. I LOVE this. She puts on a wild record as George begins to laugh again his will.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You are insane!

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
