dialogues.text: Come on old man! The music blares and the two of them go crazy. Charley is quite a sexy dancer as is George. He twists lower and low as the two of them have a Watusi competition all the time laughing. As Charley shakes her head and goes wild, she loses her balance in her mules and falls back onto George. The two them fall to the floor laughing. They are both flat on their backs as Charley slides into comfortable spot under George's arm with her head on his shoulder. They slowly calm down and their laughter turns to sweet smiles of exhausted, drunken contentment as the record di down and turns itself off. They look blissful lying on the white shag carpet as they regain their breath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: DonвЂ™t move. George jumps up, slips off his jacket and tosses a few pillows to the floor. He grabs their drinks, CharleyвЂ™s cigarettes and an ashtray and heads back to her. He slides back down next to her, lights two cigarettes at the same time, gives one to her, and takes the other one himself.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Very smooth cigarette move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to do that.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You donвЂ™t even smoke.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, not for the last 16 years. Jim hated. WhatвЂ™s to stop me now. ItвЂ™s not as if itвЂ™s going to kill me is it? They both laugh and blow smoke into the air.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: This is so nice lying here with you. DonвЂ™t you ever miss this? What we could have been to each other? Having a real relationship and kids?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: (stunned) I had Jim.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I know, but I mean a real relationship. Geo, letвЂ™s be honest, what you and Jim had was great but wasnвЂ™t it really just a substitute for something else? George sits up and looks directly at Charley.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that really what you think after all of these years? That Jim was just a substitute for real love? George really loses his temper.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Jim wasnвЂ™t a substitute for anything, and there is no substitute for Jim, anywhere! And (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: by the way, what was so REAL about your relationship with Richard? He left you after 9 years! Jim and I were together for 16 years and if he hadnвЂ™t died we would still be together! What the hell is not REAL about that!? George, disgusted, gets up and stands in front of the fir He stands dead still for a moment trying to compose himse Charley is stunned and doesnвЂ™t move. Charley has been stung by GeorgeвЂ™s comments about her marriage.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: I didnвЂ™t mean it the way it sounded. I know how much the two of you loved each other

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I just suppose that I was always a bit jealous that you and I never had that kind of love. Actually I've never had that kind of love with anyone. I donвЂ™t think Richard ever loved me except for the way I looked. And Clay, I donвЂ™t know. You raise a child and love it and then when they get old enough they just leave.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Charlotte, there is nothing wrong with your life. You like feeling sorry for yourself. ItвЂ™s one of your great pleasures.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: And itвЂ™s not one of yours? You're as pathetic as I am.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Feeling sorry for myself is definitely not one of my great pleasures.  67. Charley struggles to stand up.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Well its not one of mine either. I donвЂ™t like feeling sorry for myself one bit. I tried to hold onto Richard for so long even when it was obvious to everyone but me that it was over. Now Clay is grown up. I mean, what am I doing here Geo? Tell me that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You have lots of friends. YouвЂ™ll be fine. Charley sighs.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Yes, I have friends. But none of them need me. And yes I have you and if you werenвЂ™t such a goddamn poof we could have all been happy! George begins to smile. Charley crosses to the coffee table, lights another cigarette, takes a long drag and exhales slowly. She sits down on the sofa and George joins her. He slips his arm around her as she attempts to wriggle away.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I only have you now because you lost Jim, but IвЂ™1l lose you again soon to someone else. ItвЂ™s not as easy for a woman. I did everything the way that I was supposed to and all I have to keep me company is a bottle of gin.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Maybe you should try donuts with your gin.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Screw you!  68.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Charlotte, you are dramatic. You really almost had me. A tiny tear was beginning to form in the corner of my eye. Now stop it, you know that you are still breathtakingly beautiful when you bother to get yourself up and out of bed and you stop whimpering about everything for five minutes. Move back to London! Change your life! If you're not happy being a woman then stop acting like one.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You have all the goddamn answers donвЂ™t you? If you're so smart why arenвЂ™t YOU making something new happen in your life? (beat) IвЂ™m serious. Why donвЂ™t you take that position at Stanford? Why do you keep teaching at that little school when you could have any position you want?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think what IвЂ™ve done has been worthwhile. George is stung.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry, I shouldn't have said that. (beat) As much as I dread it, I think I might move back to London.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why do you dread it?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: When I lived in London last I was YOUNG. I was fresh, I was everything. Coming to America was (MORE )

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: such a dream, it was the icing on the cake. Going home is defeat. None of it really worked out the way I'd planned.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Most things donвЂ™t work out the way people plan. YouвЂ™re living in the past. You need to start thinking about the future.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: Living in the past IS my future. You're a man. It doesnвЂ™t have to be yours. They both sit silently for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And you're a bore tonight. CanвЂ™t we just feel sorry for ourselves a little bit longer? Mix me up another drink. Please? George checks his watch. 10:45.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t think so. I have to go. Come on. Walk me out. He gets up and takes his jacket from the back of the sofa

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: But this was such fun!

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I have to. Charley gets up and follows him as they walk toward the entry hall.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: When will I see you again?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ArenвЂ™t you moving to London?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: IвЂ™1l never do that! ItвЂ™s far too much effort. Besides, I donвЂ™t think Jim would want me to leave you here in LA all alone.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Don't worry about me Charley. IвЂ™m OK. IвЂ™ve got all the answers. Remember?

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: What are you doing this weekend?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think I might just be very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLEY
dialogues.text: You never really did take me seriously did you George? George opens the door, turns and faces her.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I tried to Charley. Remember? A long time ago. It didnвЂ™t quite work, did it? Good night Charley. As they embrace, she kisses him hard. For a moment he kis her back until her kiss turns serious and desperate. George calmly backs up and looks into her eyes. With both hands, he firmly grips her arms and kisses her again on t mouth but this time it is a chaste good-bye kiss. Charley behaves. She is defeated and we feel that this sc has been played out before in their relationship. GEORGE (CONTвЂ™D) Sleep tight. I love you. She resigns herself to him leaving, and stares at the bac of the door as he closes it behind him. EXT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE SANTA MONICA. NIGHT -- LATER. (1962  71. An exterior shot of the full moon through the trees. George's house is illuminated in the background.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George is sitting at his desk writing a note. George seals the note and then picks up the gun and holds for a moment as he places the gun gently to his head.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: George walks up the sidewalk towards the bar. It is a liv scene outside with the bar crowd spilling out onto the sidewalk. George approaches the door and pushes himself inside.

dialogues.speaker: FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: The bar is packed and filled with many men in their Naval uniforms. It is also filled with girls who have clearly dolled themselves up for the evening. All are laughing and talking loudly. It is a wild and raucous atmosphere and filled with so much smoke that it hard to see. George walks in and not being able to find a spot to stan orders a beer and a pack of cigarettes at the bar and goe outside to smoke and enjoy the cool breeze.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: George is standing outside enjoying his cigarette as a yo Naval officer walks into the bar. George briefly locks eyes with the young man. After a few moments, the young officer returns with a beer - itвЂ™s J

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s too hot in there.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes it is. Would you like a cigarette?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks, I donвЂ™t smoke. Is this place always this crowded?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, it is Saturday night but no itвЂ™s usually not quite this bad. Most people just stop in here to pick someone up and then head on down the beach for the rest of the evening.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Yeah. ItвЂ™s pretty wild out there. IвЂ™m surprised the cops donвЂ™t break it up. Is it always like that?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Since the war ended. I think itвЂ™s pretty great actually. Kind of pagan. Jim puts his hand out.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Jim. The two men shake hands.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: George. Pleased to meet you Jim.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m supposed to meet some friends here but they're nowhere to be found.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I just needed to get out of the house. I was just going to take a walk but the lure of a cold beer got to me. George puts out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Do you live close by?  73.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Yes. In the canyon.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: How long have you lived here?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Since 38. Where are you from?

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Colorado. But I really like it here. I think I might stay after IвЂ™m discharged. ItвЂ™s great. I love being so close to the ocean. I donвЂ™t know, perhaps IвЂ™m just a bit of a pagan. Just then it begins to rain lightly. The two men look at each other and then scramble for the door to the bar as t rain starts coming down hard and fast.

dialogues.speaker: CONTINUOUS
dialogues.text: It is packed inside and George and Jim are literally pres up against each other. There is an electricity between th two of them. It is so loud inside the bar that they have shout.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Another beer?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That would be great. Just then a beautiful BLONDE GIRL with Veronica Lake hair and a cherry red mouth, pushes between the two of them. A she does she looks up at Jim.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE GIRL
dialogues.text: Well, hello.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: Hello.  74.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE GIRL
dialogues.text: Want to buy me a drink? Jim looks past the girl directly into GeorgeвЂ™s eyes.

dialogues.speaker: JIM
dialogues.text: I'm afraid IвЂ™m taken.

dialogues.speaker: BLONDE GIRL
dialogues.text: Too bad. Too bad... She pushes away from them back into the crowd as the two smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: END FLASHBACK
dialogues.text: INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - STUDY. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS George sits still for a moment, puts the gun down, jumps and runs down the hall to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: OUR VIEW IS FROM OUTSIDE OF THE HOUSE.
dialogues.text: George crosses to the liquor cabinet and grabs the bottle scotch. There is only a drop left. George puts down the bottle, takes off his glasses and go out the front door.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMPHOR TREE LANE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: As George leaves his driveway he hears someone behind him We see clearly the outline of KennyвЂ™s bike in the foreg but George doesnвЂ™t see this. He stops and looks around. Nothing. George continues his down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STARBOARD SIDE BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: George approaches the bar. He opens the door and goes in. The place is a faded version of its 1946 incarnation.  75.

dialogues.speaker: INT. STARBOARD SIDE BAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The bar now sports a jukebox in the corner and a televisi above it. A neon Budweiser sign/clock tells us it is 11:0 Most of the patrons sit at the long bar, staring lazily a the television in a cow daze. George heads to the bar and calls out to PATRICK the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Patrick, could I have a bottle of scotch and a pack of Lucky Strikes to go please? As he says this he notices a young man who walks into the bar. A slow steady smile crosses George's face - itвЂ™s Kenny. George looks to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Patrick. Cancel that. He holds up two fingers and points to his regular booth. Patrick nods. George walks over to the booth. Kenny slips onto the bench across from George. Kenny is slightly out of breath.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, hello Mr. Potter.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Hello, sir. The bartender places their drinks in front of them. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) What are we drinking?  76.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Scotch.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: They each take a sip.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I come here all the time. I live around the corner, but then you know that.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: On Camphor Tree Lane. They smile at each other. George reaches into his pants pocket, pulls out his penci sharpener, and places it on the table with a smile. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) You're still carrying that around.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: One must always appreciate life's little gifts. Kenny and George smile at each other.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what are you doing here?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Just out for a ride on my bike.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Is that all?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Were you looking for me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe. I donвЂ™t know. I feel like my headвЂ™s stopped up with stuff, with crap.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Stuff like what?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Like, the stuff you were talking about today in class.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That is definitely not important.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: No, it is important. Your class is great. But somehow we always seem to get stuck talking about the past. The past just doesnвЂ™t matter to me

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And the present?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I canвЂ™t wait for the present to be over. ItвЂ™s a total drag. Well tonight's the exception

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George bursts into laughter.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Tonight - yes! The present - no! Let's drink to tonight! They clink glasses.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Tonight! They both take a sip.  78.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: So if the past doesnвЂ™t matter and the present is a вЂњtotal dragвЂќ. what about the future?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: What future? I mean Cuba might just blow us up.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Death is the future.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m sorry. I donвЂ™t mean to be depressing.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: ItвЂ™s not depressing, itвЂ™s true. I mean, itвЂ™s not necessarily your immediate future, but itвЂ™s what we all share. Death is the future.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: You're right I guess.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If one is not enjoying oneвЂ™s present there isnвЂ™t a great deal to suggest that the future should be any better.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah, IвЂ™ve thought that before. But the thing is, you just never know. Look at tonight. George looks intently at Kenny. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Actually I feel really alone most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You do?  79.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Yeah. IвЂ™ve always felt this way. I mean we're born alone, we die alone. And while we're here we are absolutely, completely sealed in our own bodies. Really weird. Kinda freaks me out to think about it. We can only experience the outside world through our own slanted perception of it. Who knows what you're really like. I just see what I think you're like.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m exactly what I seem to be, if you look closely. You know the only thing that has made the whole thing worthwhile has been those few times that I was able to truly connect with another person

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I had a hunch about you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Yes, sir. I had a hunch you might be a real romantic. George smiles. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) You know, everyone keeps telling you that when you're older, that you'll have all this experience - like itвЂ™s some great thing

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: That's a load of shit. I think IвЂ™ve actually just gotten sillier and sillier.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Really?  80.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Absolutely.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: So all your experience is useless?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, I wouldnвЂ™t say that. As our friend Mr. Huxley says: вЂњExperience is not what happens to a man; it is what a man does with what happens to him.вЂќ Kenny looks at George and then blurts out...

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: LetвЂ™s go swimming.

dialogues.speaker: OK.
dialogues.text: Kenny bursts into laughter. George is confused but grins anyway.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: It was a test. I thought you were bluffing about being silly, so I said to myself, I'll suggest doing something completely outrageous and if he resists, if he even hesitates - then I know heвЂ™s full of shit.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Well, I wasnвЂ™t. Were you?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Hell no! They both jump up. George throws a few bills on the table and follows Kenny out of the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They break into a run as Kenny sprints across the highway without looking either way. George struggles to keep up.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SANTA MONICA STATE BEACH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: As George runs across the highway - Kenny vaults over the railing and disappears. George clambers over the guard rail and looks down at Ken the street lights shining on his grinning face.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Come on sir. I'll help you down George drops to the sand.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Let's go. Kenny turns and runs, whooping and pulling off his clothe George follows. As he watches Kenny undress he hesitates momentarily and then begins to unbutton his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SURF LINE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A naked Kenny runs toward the surf and fearlessly dives i the waves. Seeing Kenny, George toughens up. He slips off his pants, runs after Kenny and dives in. A wave splashes over George and he stumbles. He finds his balance and continues out. George makes his way out further, still laughing, as Kenn continues to plunge in and out of the waves. Emboldened by Kenny's enthusiasm, George wades out further, his arms outstretched.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SANTA MONICA STATE BEACH. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A naked George is way out and almost out of his depth as towering wave pulls the surf away from him. George tries brace himself against the giant wave but instead he is  82. knocked flat and suddenly pulled underwater. He does not resurface. Kenny dives under water to look for George.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George gasps for air as Kenny pulls him to the surface an drags him toward the beach.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: ThatвЂ™s enough for now sir

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m fine.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Well IвЂ™m not. IвЂ™m cold. Come on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny gets George to their clothes and starts toweling himself off.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: can we go back to your place sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Of course. Where else? George begins dressing.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Where else. Kenny smiles and grabs the rest of his clothes, heading b toward the highway still naked.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Are you out of your mind?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You canвЂ™t walk home like that! George catches up with Kenny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WeвЂ™re invisible, donвЂ™t you know that? 83. George stops dead in his tracks with this line from Kenny George is very cold, but Kenny seems in his element. He p his arm around George's shoulders.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You know sir, they ought not to let you out on your own. You're liable to get into real trouble.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Oh, I excel at it. Kenny looks at George who has a small cut over his left e

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Your forehead is bleeding. George reaches up and touches his brow. He looks at his h and sees the blood on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They enter the house. Kenny is full of energy and George sobered up a little from the walk back.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: The bathroom is down the hall if you would like to take a shower

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: ArenвЂ™t you taking a shower too, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m fine. IвЂ™m English. We like to be cold and wet.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: First, I think that we need to take care of that cut sir. Do you have any band-aids?  84.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny and George walk into the bedroom Kenny looks at the sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Going camping sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Really, IвЂ™m fine.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Stay there. I'll be right back George sits down on the sleeping bag.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny walks into the bathroom. He opens the drawer next to the sink and pulls out a cotton ball and a bottle of alcohol. He finds a tin of band-aids. As he lifts it up something catches his eye. It is the nude photograph of dim, taken in the desert. Kenny stares at the picture a moment, looks towards the bedroom, and then quickly puts it back in the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kenny returns to the bedroom where George is lying flat o the bed with his feet on the ground.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: sit up. George obeys much to his surprise, as Kenny seems suddenl in control. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Tilt your head back Kenny gently cleans George's forehead with a cotton ball soaked in alcohol. George winces slightly but his eyes ar locked on his new friend. Kenny puts a band-aid across th  85. cut over GeorgeвЂ™s brow and gently brushes his wet hair with his fingers. KENNY (CONTвЂ™D) Well sir, IвЂ™m afraid this time you donвЂ™t have the excuse of mescaline to explain your bandage.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I think that we need to get you out of those wet clothes.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Yes sir. Kenny stands up and moves to the corner next to a chair. kicks off his shoes and undresses very slowly. He careful lays his clothes on the chair. Standing nude, Kenny turns towards George. He looks shy and nervous. George, who sti sits on the edge of the bed, does not take his eyes off o Kenny. Kenny smiles sweetly at George, but George does not react Suddenly embarrassed, Kenny turns and walks into the bathroom. He doesnвЂ™t close the door after him but is ou of GeorgeвЂ™s sight. The shower is turned on. George is not sure what to do. Looking towards the bathro he contemplates going in but instead rushes to his closet and grabs his robe. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - LIVING ROOM. NIGHT -- MINUTES LAT George lights a fire. He turns on the Hi-Fi and adjusts the lights. Kenny comes into the room, wrapped in a grey blanket.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're not too cold?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I'm great.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Would you like a drink?  86.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I'd love a beer sir, if you have one.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m afraid thatвЂ™s all we have. Two beers, coming up. Kenny is examining an architectural model next to the drafting table as George arrives and hands him his beer.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: You live here all by yourself, sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I do now. I used to share this place with a friend. He was an architect.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Man, guys my age dream about the kind of setup youвЂ™ve got here. I mean, what more can you want? You get to be left alone and come and go as you please.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And thatвЂ™s your idea of the perfect life?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: WhatвЂ™s the matter, sir? You donвЂ™t believe me?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: If you're so keen on living by yourself, where does Lois fit into this plan?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Lois? WhatвЂ™s she got to do with anything?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I had the impression that you and she were together.  87.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Not really. I mean sheвЂ™s kind of cool and we're good friends, but I think what you really want to ask me is if we sleep together

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: And do you?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: We did. Once.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why only once?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I didnвЂ™t say only once, I said once. Come on, the last thing I want to talk about right now is Lois.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What time is it? George looks at his watch. The second hand is not moving the case is clouded over.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: I donвЂ™t know. My watch seems to have stopped. George bangs his watch on the table.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: What does it matter anyway.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Would you like me to go?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: No, are you kidding? Get us both another beer. Kenny jumps up and heads to the kitchen, then looks back.  88.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Is that an order sir?

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: You're damn right it is! George tries to get up, but he struggles, quite drunk now and falls back into his chair.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (to himself) Pathetic. Kenny arrives with two bottles of beer.

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Were you saying something sir? George gives Kenny a concentrated stare.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Why are you here? Why did you ask the secretary in the office for my address?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: I just wanted to see you someplace other than school.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: KENNY
dialogues.text: Sometimes I think IвЂ™m crazy because I see things so differently than everyone else does. I feel like I can talk to you. To be honest sir I was also worried about you today.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE
dialogues.text: Me? WhatвЂ™s to be worried about? IвЂ™m fine. George's vision begins to blur as Kenny moves toward us. image fades to a dusky brown.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: IвЂ™m fine...  89.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are underwater in GeorgeвЂ™s recurring dream. From the of our screen drifts the nude body of George, arms outstretched, sinking slowly. He moves his legs in a slig struggle as he drops further and further underwater. Geor begins to toss and turn violently in the water searching air. This time he suddenly rights himself and begins push toward the surface of the water. He climbs higher and hig and hits the surface with a loud gasp for air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George wakes up in bed with a deep gasp for air. He looks around the room for a moment. He is still dresse in his robe. The light is on. He looks to the chair- KennyвЂ™s clothes are still there. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S HOUSE - STUDY. NIGHT -- CONTINUOUS George walks into the study. In the faint light we see Ke asleep on the sofa underneath the blanket. George stands over Kenny a minute looking at him. The lig is catching on KennyвЂ™s thick lashes. Kenny is breathing gently. He looks angelic, and very, very, young. Kenny's hands are holding onto something under the blanke George carefully pulls the blanket back to reveal Kenny loosely gripping George's gun. George reaches down and gently lifts the gun out of Kenny hand and pulls the blanket up over Kenny's chest. As George stares down at Kenny asleep, a warm smile creep across his face. George crosses the room and stares at the desk top. It ha been disturbed. His perfect grid of papers is out of orde He opens the desk drawer and puts the gun carefully insid  90. He lifts the key out of the drawer, locks the desk and sl the key into the pocket of his robe. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S BEDROOM NIGHT 1962--CONTINUOUS. George walks towards the glass door that opens to his bac yard. It is a beautiful night. We can hear the sound of t surf in the distance and the sounds of the crickets and frogs. An enormous owl almost 2 feet tall is sitting perfectly still in a branch of the large pine tree directly outside the glass door at eye level with George but George does n see this. As he opens the door the owl suddenly spreads i wings and takes flight. As this happens our sound stops abruptly and we are left total silence. George freezes, gazing at the full amber colored moon, an drinking in the feeling of the fresh air. It is clear from his face that he is a different man. He free. The cloud has lifted. George bats his eyes and as he does our sound snaps back. GEORGE V.O. A few times in my life IвЂ™ve had moments of absolute clarity. George walks back into the study and stands over Kenny an smiles.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.0., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: When for a few brief seconds the silence drowns out the noise and I can feel rather than think... George goes to the desk, gathers the note to Charley and of the other letters.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And things seem so sharp and the world seems so fresh.  91. He turns out the lamp and quietly closes the double doors the study leaving Kenny asleep on the sofa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: George slips down the hall to the living room which is st illuminated by the embers of the dying fire. He throws th letters into the fireplace and watches them flare up. He puts his hands in the pockets of his robe and lets out deep sigh. GEORGE V.O. I can never make these moments last. I cling to them, but like everything they fade. The golden light from the fire rakes across GeorgeвЂ™s fa he beams. INT. GEORGEвЂ™S BEDROOM NIGHT 1962 -- MOMENTS LATER. George sits on the edge of his bed. He is ecstatic. GEORGE V.O. I have lived my live on these moments.

dialogues.speaker: CUT BACK TO
dialogues.text: INT. GEORGEвЂ™S BEDROOM NIGHT 1962--CONTINUOUS. GEORGE V.O. They pull me back to the present George is sitting on his bed reveling in his new found peace.

dialogues.speaker: GEORGE V.O., (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: and I realize that everything is exactly the way it was meant to be.  92. George, still smiling, reaches towards his bedside table pour himself a glass of water from the carafe. As he does this his arm goes numb - he canвЂ™t use his hand. He trie again and then grabs onto his wrist with his other hand. We see a look of disbelief in GeorgeвЂ™s face as there is suddenly a sharp pain in his chest. His face is contorted with panic. He tries to cry out but can only muster a slight moan. George attempts to stand but falls to the floor. As he do he hits the night stand violently with his body. The clock hits the floor breaking its face. George lies silently on the floor. He begins to lose consciousness. There is no sound except for the sound of the clock which ticks loudly for a few beats and then abruptly stops.

dialogues.speaker: FROM THE CEILING, WE PUSH IN SLOWLY UNTIL WE ARE JUST OVE
dialogues.text: GEORGEвЂ™S BODY. WE ARE INTIMATE WITH HIM AND HEAR HIM BREATHING. Into our warm brown screen moves slowly an EVER CLOSER SO FOCUS SHOT OF JIM. Jim moves toward us as FOCUS SHARPENS he comes in for a very gentle kiss. JimвЂ™s face fills ou screen and then he pulls away slowly and recedes into the darkness. We settle, in an intimate way, close to GeorgeвЂ™s face. quite literally feel him slip away from us. The sounds of life grow increasingly faint. George lets o a deep but relaxed sigh as his jaw slackens and his eyes begin to glaze and lose focus. George is completely motionless but he now has the faintest smile on his face. The room is warm and dark and pleasant.  93. Shot from above, George's face fills our screen as we slo pull back. GEORGE V.0. (CONTвЂ™D) And just like that it came. We are now high above George and his outstretched body fi our screen as our image gradually begins to desaturate an then bleaches to white as we - CUT TO BLACK.
